@paulk-asert  What do you think about the PR?

I get different results to the summary above. Perhaps I am running a different test. I don't have a space in my `user.home` directory. I don't know whether that makes a difference. For me I get:
```
file: Windows OK, Ubuntu OK (status quo)
file:/ Windows OK, Ubuntu KO
file:// Windows KO, Ubuntu OK
file:/// Windows OK, Ubuntu OK
user.home Windows C:\Users\paulk, Ubuntu /home/paulk
```
For the record, my testing involved running the following script:
```
@Grab('org.apache.commons:commons-lang3:3.6B')
import static org.apache.commons.lang3.math.Fraction.*
assert ONE_THIRD.multiplyBy(ONE_HALF).denominator == 6
```
Where 3.6B was just a copy of 3.6 in my `.m2` directory with the POM suitably corrected and the sha1 files removed. This was just to ensure I wasn't getting that version from anywhere else. I removed the corresponding entries in the `.groovy/grapes` cache after each successful attempt.
I copied the `defaultGrapeConfig.xml` from the repo source into `~/.groovy/grapeConfig.xml` as is and only changed the number of slashes after `file:`.

with the provided script on Windows I have these results:

> file: Windows OK --> this one was not working in the reported case but working with provided script
> file:/ Windows OK
> file:// Windows KO
> file:/// Windows KO

@jaikiran i'm wondering if the openjdk and oracle jdk are not behaving differently for this "file:" stuff, on a server we had a lot of errors of ivy cache in log, I changed from openjdk to oracle jdk and there are no more errors. I think that it might explain the difference of result that we have. Not sure when i will have time to test it properly.

+1. It begs the question about whether other annotations should have special treatment, e.g. should @SafeVarargs or @SuppressWarnings be transferred only onto the new internal method and be removed from the original? But I see no reason why the approach being used couldn't be extended over time to handle such cases - it will all be "invisible" to the user.

I tried numerous "simpler" solutions but the INFERRED_TYPE metadata is used in many places and changing that info earlier led to problems like call-site writing with too specific types, so I stashed away the instanceof info under the INFERRED_RETURN_TYPE key and pull it out later when needed. Happy to hear of simpler ways of doing this if anyone can see an alternative.
Thanks for picking this up so quickly, @jwagenleitner.
This was merged with an identical commit. Thanks.
LGTM. How about we change the since version to 2.6.0 and merge into master and GROOVY_2_6_X?
Merged!
Thanks Paul, I updated the since tags and merged into the branches suggested.
This looks good at first glance. Nice work! I'll have a bit more of an in-depth look during the week.
I created an issue to track this: GROOVY-8347
Merged! Thanks! I have some minor tweaks but I'll do them after the fact.
Great G-)

I made some minor modifications:

- added support for annotating a field or local variable assigned a closure value (only needed for fine-grained application of this annotation)
- automatically processed inner classes if annotated at the class level
- added guards to avoid processing twice (if say at both the class and method level - it's an idempotent change but more efficient)
- if annotated at the method level, automatically covers closures within that method

If we do ever add configuration options via annotation attributes, the processing changes above should put us in a good place, e.g. if you use configscript to turn on for all classes, you could turn off for one class with something like one of either of these:
```
@AutoFinal(enabled=false)
@AutoFinal(methods=false, constructors=false, innerClasses=false, closures=false)
```

Let me know what you think. I haven't completed the tests yet.

* Looks all good to me G-)
* Even though I am generally all in favor of giving people options, still convinced disabling AutoFinal locally makes no sense in practice, and it might even be a bad idea to support that (especially at the class level - least suprise an' all...)
* Could ask in Groovy users group, though, if someone can come up with an example where e.g. AutoFinal(enabled=false) at the method level would make sense...

"Least surprise" is possibly like beauty ... in the eye of the beholder. If I see an `AutoFinal(disabled=true)`, I might be quite surprised until I realised a configscript is in place - which might be even more surprising if I didn't know that ahead of time. :-)

* "Least surprise" in this case means I can trust that all parameters everywhere are final. One cannot apply "least surprise" to global settings, because they are, well, global, so whoever enables the global setting is responsible for making everyone involved aware of the setting (so that `AutoFinal(disabled=true)` does not confuse anyone).
* The alternative is to put AutoFinal explcitely on every class, and enforce this with a check-in-code-rule.

I think we are in agreement. I made changes to allow disabling. Let me know what you think.

I haven't finished extra tests yet. If you have time to work on some of those, that would help me out a lot; otherwise, I'll do them later this week.

Merged, thanks. For future reference, you might want to rebase against master just before creating your PR. I just merged the two commits instead of the PR this time. Git might have been smart enough to deal with the noise but I wasn't going to muck around and find out.

I get the same failures locally as travis-ci. I haven't had time to fully investigate but it seems like we can get away without setting a source unit when we create little snippets by hand (in our test code for instance) so long as we don't have any annotations in those snippets. While I wonder whether checking for version >= jdk5 with `isAnnotationCompatible` is even needed anymore it might just be best to not add the `Generated` annotation if we don't find a source unit? What do you think?

The test for `@Generated` was adapted from the one for `@Immutable` hence the check. @paulk-assert if you think it's worth removing then sure, I can remove it 😄  What other changes should be made to the test case?
FYI: The filter for the new annotation will be part of JaCoCo 0.8.0 release soon.

Hi @Nektro thanks for the PR. The purpose of that `ArrayUtils` class is to ease bytecode generation and avoid needing to write bytecodes to generate an array as is needed for the varargs. The class comments show an example and explains why the individual methods are needed and they are statically linked to in generated bytecode by the `CallsiteWriter`.
Thanks!
@jwagenleitner sorry about that didn't see that it wasn't used in your actual program. Interesting JIT quirk you all found. Feel free to close :)
I pushed the branch. I do agree we should have a guideline for when to use it and when not. But I think we should first start using it and then decide what we want to advice

On the one hand, the JLS[1] says: "_A nested enum type is implicitly_ `static`", so your proposed change looks good. However it goes on to say that "_This implies that it is impossible to declare an enum type in the body of an inner class_". With some simple experimenting, it seems Groovy doesn't have this same restriction. I think we just need to do a little more checking that such cases aren't adversely affected (or understand if they are). I'll try to play around a little more myself but have other things on the TODO list first.

[1] [8.9. Enum Types](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.9)

@paulk-asert That's an interesting case. I added a few variations of my original test to cover that along with static compilation. Looking at the byte code, enums nested within inner classes don't seem to have any references to instances of their enclosing classes, so I'd *think* this would be ok. I'll try to test this with some ecosystem projects when I have time.
Merged, thanks!
Merged, thanks!

+1 for this to be merged to at least 2_5_X. I suspect there are further cases which differ from Java which need to be clarified but I think this takes us in the right direction and it will be further locking down to rule out cases that don't really make sense that Groovy appears to support but doesn't really and can be done outside the scope of this PR.

Thanks for moving this forward.  One concern I had is on Linux/Unix/MacOSX is accidental replacement of a common path.  For example if your project working directory was "/home" or "/" (heaven forbid), you could replace "/home/users/name/home/project/xyz" with "./users/name./project/xyz".

This was not a concern for my Windows testing, since a drive name always roots the absolute path.
Good point. I adjusted the patch accordingly.
Test added.

With the original code (pre-PR) I get 70k indy and 3k non-indy. With the PR as is I get 30k for both indy and non-indy. Testing with commented out `or` change I get 70k for indy and 30k for non-indy. In other words, the commented out code has the same improved performance for non-indy and doesn't reduce indy perf (based on my benchmark runs).

Was there a reason to leave the commented out statement or was it the intent to use that in the PR instead of the current statement?

Sorry, it did not cross my mind to run the benchmark using indy. Is there an easy way to do so?

The commented out code, which I was not intending to commit, was my initial attempt at fixing the issue. My worry was that using the `or` condition introduces an additional call to the getter which might be significant for non trivial getter implementations. I could evaluate the getter once and store it in a variable but that would lead to a more complex solution. Switching receiver and argument of the `is()` call felt like a simpler solution. I was not aware that it will have negative impact on indy performance.

Should we go with the null check solution whoch does not degrade indy performance and ignore the additional evaluation of the getter it introduces for non null property values? I’m more than happy to ammend the PR in the morning.
We could potentially optimise this a little further by using node metadata instead of redoing some of the checks for the inner class case but I'll likely leave that as a future activity.

If you add `-Pindy=true` argument when executing the `jmh` task it should compile the test groovy code using `indy`. For example, I ran:

`./gradlew -PbenchInclude=GeneratedHashCode -Pindy=true :perf:jmh`

I'd be curious if you also see similar numbers. As you say, adding the null check may have a perf hit for non-trivial uses so maybe the decrease in indy perf is not as bad as it look.

I am actually wondering... isn't `notX(sameX(fieldExpr, varX("this"))` The same as  `!this.@x.is(this)`,with x being a field? I assume we have this to avoid stack overflows... I have two comments to this actually:
1) I think we should not support that case
2) If we support it, it is better to create a binary expression with the token `COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL` or `!==`. Even if the language does not support it directly, the compiler does afaik since at least groovy++. That way there would be not even a dynamic call.
Merged, thanks!

The first three bullet points are non-controversial changes - the file was originally a Java file and wasn't refactored much when changed to Groovy. The null on the LHS probably requires more discussion on the mailing list. There are places where we try to hide NPEs and other places we don't. We value consistency across all cases ahead of commutativity (consistency between LHS and RHS).

Splitting into two PRs or at least two commits would make it easier to progress the non-controversial changes.

These are the results I'm getting. I also included an implementation using `COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL` as suggested by Jochen. Let me know what you want me to do. :)

pre-PR, null property/field
non-indy 3k
indy 100K

pre-PR, non-null property/field
non-indy 25k
indy 27k

`is()` receiver and arg switched, null property/field
non-indy 31k
indy 33k

`is()` receiver and arg switched, non-null property/field
non-indy 27k
indy 28k

`or`, null property/field
non-indy 39k
indy 99k

`or`, non-null property/field
non-indy 23k
indy 28k

`COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL`, null property/field
non-indy 40k
indy 98k

`COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL`, non-null property/field
non-indy 32k
indy 86k
welll... for me that speaks clearly for COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL
Suggestions incorporated and merged.
Merged, thanks.
+1 for COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL
I updated the fix to use `COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL` and force pushed.

This has been merged onto master and GROOVY_2_6_X. We'd have more work to do for GROOVY_2_4_X and GROOVY_2_5_X since currently BinaryExpressionHelper#eval has code which triggers a SyntaxException for COMPARE_NOT_IDENTICAL.
That's a bummer but it is what it is. :)
Merged, thanks.

> @apupier, I wasn't following that JIRA so hadn't noticed your update which included the steps to reproduce. Thanks for letting me know. I'll give it a try in the next few days and see how it goes.

@jaikiran Had you have time to have a look?

I see it is not adding the @Generated annotation to get/set methods generated by groovy for private variables.  As a result code coverage reports are still not that accurate as code coverage reports still show get/set methods not covered.
You mean for example in class X{def y} the getY and setY method?
Yes..

Do we really need Lambda in groovy.lang? We do have Closure and Lambda extends Closure, why should we have Lambda in groovy.lang as well? There is no need to have it as parameter in any API imho. Instead I would go directly for GeneratedLambda only. Also we should consider making the new classes in here use the apache package structure instead of the codehaus one. Then about FunctionalInterface... I thought this is a documentation only marking of interfaces. Imho there is no requirement to have this annotation to use lambdas, not in Groovy and not in Java. So I would remove that kind of logic. You added getClassVisitor to ACG. I think that is available through the controller, so no need to add this. Then I do not understand the change you did with CorrectAccessedVariableVisitor. Ignoring that you made it an explicit inner class, why did you change it to extend ClassCodeVisitorSupport instead of CodeVisitorSupport? The usage is the same. Giving this visitor more capabilties that are not used is not good, a refactoring is bound to make something out of this, that it is not. Also you should undo the method visibility of removeInitialValues back to private. You are not using the method outside of the class. Then your triple DUP...what is this for? Later I see a lot of POP, which you are not doing. This hints me, that the DUPs are not required and that you do not clean the operand stack up, instead you leave it to the compiler infrastructure, which can do this to some etend, but you should not depend on it. So please add the POPs yourself. or avoid the surplus looking DUPs.

Hi Jochen( @blackdrag  ),

     Thanks a lot for your reviewing the code.

> Do we really need Lambda in groovy.lang? We do have Closure and Lambda extends Closure, why should we have Lambda in groovy.lang as well?

I agree with you, I've removed `Lambda`

> Then about FunctionalInterface... I thought this is a documentation only marking of interfaces. Imho there is no requirement to have this annotation to use lambdas, not in Groovy and not in Java. So I would remove that kind of logic.

You're right, I've remove the check.

> Then I do not understand the change you did with CorrectAccessedVariableVisitor. 

I want to reuse its code. As you can see, `TransformationVisitor` extends `CorrectAccessedVariableVisitor` 
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/dbcac60f64f921cd5e8ee02c4af126c9a6d8b883/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/StaticTypesLambdaWriter.java#L413

>  why did you change it to extend ClassCodeVisitorSupport instead of CodeVisitorSupport?

I need to `visitMethod`, which does not exist in `CodeVisitorSupport`. Maybe I revert it to `CodeVisitorSupport` and delegate `visitVariableExpression` to a `CodeVisitorSupport` instance
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/dbcac60f64f921cd5e8ee02c4af126c9a6d8b883/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/StaticTypesLambdaWriter.java#L334

> Also you should undo the method visibility of removeInitialValues back to private. You are not using the method outside of the class.

I use `removeInitialValues` in class `StaticTypesLambdaWriter`, so we have to make it `protected`...
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/dbcac60f64f921cd5e8ee02c4af126c9a6d8b883/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/StaticTypesLambdaWriter.java#L352

> Then your triple DUP...what is this for? Later I see a lot of POP, which you are not doing. This hints me, that the DUPs are not required and that you do not clean the operand stack up, instead you leave it to the compiler infrastructure, which can do this to some etend, but you should not depend on it. So please add the POPs yourself. or avoid the surplus looking DUPs.

Jochen, I tried to pop just now, but failed.. the stack seems to be empty already(see `java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: size==0 `). Any further hints for me?
https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/552e01039aaad874a1409f4029df132817c7b0bb/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/sc/StaticTypesLambdaWriter.java#L163-L177
